ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Italian L1-L2 skills; reading and aural skills; oral conversational skills

I learned elementary Italian in the realms of conversation, composition, and comprehension. The introduction to Italian culture and society as it related to the material in class was also really wonderful.
italian
Learned how to speak Italian to a fairly proficient level - lots of vocabulary and extensive grammar was covered

I gained a shocking level of proficiency in Italian. At the start of the semester, Michael said that by the term's end, we students would be able to converse on any topic. I heavily doubted him, but he was exactly right. This course also forced me to develop some better study habits than I had back in February.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course, though of course content moves quickly. I wish there was a slightly more organized approach to grammatical concepts.

The biggest strength of the course was Michael, our professor. He is so passionate about Italian and ensuring his students are enjoying their experience in the course as well as learning the language. He is also really funny and injects humor into our lessons. This course was incredible and so much fun. There are no areas of improvement (aside from the remote, virtual format).
i loved this course!

Strengths: prof. Farina is very knowledgeable and engaging, the discussion and immersion format forces you to know the material
Weaknesses: lessons on grammar could be improved by going a little more in depth and explaining more thoroughly, personally I learned most of the grammar on my own just using the textbook and was expected to know it

Strengths - Michael, Michael, Michael. One of the best teachers I've had. You'll get lots of comments about how affirming and encouraging and understanding he is, all true. He's also a hell of a teacher. Teaching grammar is kind of a weird thing, because those who master it often don't have a sense of the rules -- it's just intuitive. Michael explained grammar in a very easy to understand way, offering extremely helpful tips and mnemonic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was wonderfully adapted as class meetings were held over Zoom which simulated in-person meetings as close as possible.
Nothing to be improved

It was as good as it could be. Language seminars probably suffered the most from the virtual learning, but I thought we all still formed a community and learned a lot. Don't have recommendations for improvement. Michael's teaching kept everybody engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely would recommend this course if you want to improve your Italian or begin a new language.

Yes, I would 1000% recommend this course. Although it is a lot of work with L1 and L2 combined into one course, it was incredibly engaging and rewarding. There is a lot of work, but it is manageable. There are daily quizzes on the material we go over in class, which was helpful in keeping us accountable and on-pace.
definitely! great class for first time Italian learners looking for a challenge

Yes, I thought it was an engaging and fun language course that I would recommend. The workload is definitely heavy but prof. Farina is a great professor and makes it interesting while you learn alongside other people just learning Italian
100% take it. Prof Farina is the best.

Absolutely, 100% yes. Especially if you have a background in Spanish but don't want to continue Spanish here, this is the course for you. I was nearly scared off by reviews that talked about a high workload. I honestly didn't experience that at all. The workload is high, but Michael isn't oblivious to that, and he paces the course and grades the assignment bearing in mind the high demand of the work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Virtual seminar/discussion sort of format
Daily two-hours zoom seminars
